title: Does anyone think Ariana Grande is overexposed and will experience a flop soon? Hate is growing and her songs are getting more basic. - Quora

response.answer_text: well, she’s at her peak at the moment and Thank U, Next has brought her much respect and popularity within the industry. and with that, there’s also more haters. it’s sort of a pattern with all artists. the more people know you, the more people form an opinion on you. and the more people form an opinion on you, the more they criticise you in whatever way they can. we can’t deny that she’s earned hate and people find her basic more these days. it’s sort of what happens with being famous unfortunately. some people actually don’t like her and some people just do it because others do. it’s with every artist, especially at their peek. her music is controversial and many people like it while many people do not. ariana addressed that she knows that people like her music and some don’t and that’s okay (2019 Zach Sang interview). her music isn’t really “basic” or “unique”. like all opinions, it’s what you interpret it as. some people find it mainstream and they’re not wrong or right. we can’t deny her songs are often pop songs and a lot of people find them basic. however, a lot of people find it unique and again it’s not wrong or right. such as me. i started becoming a fan watching her interviews and while her music didn’t make me a fan, after i started loving her because she seemed like a genuine and sweet girl, i explored her discography and loved it. i find it very healing and i love how as time passes, she’s more and more open with them. My Everything, her 2nd album was a hit and was more focused on songs that people would like rather than what she herself liked. so was Dangerous Woman. she’s said she doesn’t like songs such as Why Try, Bang Bang and Touch It which were included on her earlier albums. however, now you’ll find she loves her newer songs and is more focused on what she wants to do. without a doubt, her 2 latest albums have been much more close to her heart. she participated in writing every song on Thank U, Next and her newer songs were based on personal experiences or more light-hearted songs that she wrote for fun. however, recent pop culture has most likely influenced her sound and they may sound generic to many people. some people like her music and some don’t. we don’t know the future but seeing her rising fame, it’s not unlikely she’ll have a “flop” era when it comes to non-listeners. she’s doing quite well with her music right now and also healing mentally from her trauma she’s been through. she seems to be in a good place right now but maybe in the future she won’t have a hit era and that’s okay. ups and downs come with artistry and time will tell where her career is headed. :)

Are you wondering if Ariana will suffer backlash that’s analogous to what happened to Mariah Carey when Glitter was released? That’s entirely possible. However, what you refer to as “basic,” others see as “human” or “conversational.” Ariana has displayed a knack for tapping into ways of making music in the current pop music environment that allow her to be a diva but still relevant. As your “question” suggests, there will always be hate when an artist experiences great success. That phenomenon is the very origin of the word “hater” as a distinct label for someone who is resentful or jealous of someone’s success, often simply because of the success itself and not because of any underlying rationalization that the negative feeling is righteous and justified because the artist in some way didn’t deserve the success. Ariana will not always be as popular or successful as she is now, but that only reflects the way popularity and success cycles work. It won’t “prove” she is overexposed or that her artistic output is inferior. It happens to all artists.
